dublinCore.dc:title: 115 HR 2649 IH: Safe and Accountable Federal Energy Review for Pipelines Act of 2017
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mrs. Watson Coleman (for herself and Mr. Cartwright) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To require the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to apply certain procedures before granting a certificate of public convenience and necessity for a proposed pipeline project, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Safe and Accountable Federal Energy Review for Pipelines Act of 2017 or the Safer Pipelines Act of 2017.

section.header: Approval of new natural gas pipelines
section.text: Section 7(e) of the Natural Gas Act (15 U.S.C. 717f(e)) is amended—

paragraph.text: by inserting (1) before Except in the cases; and
by adding at the end the following:

Before granting a certificate for a proposed pipeline expansion project for which an impacted State or political subdivision or intervener has raised a challenge to the project’s public necessity based upon factors that the Commission is required to consider including FERC Statement of Policy (88 FERC 61,227) modified by 89 FERC 61,040, further clarified by 90 FERC 61,128, the Commission shall—

subparagraph.text: assign the application to an administrative law judge who shall, as appropriate—

clause.text: hold a full trial-type evidentiary hearing on any contested issue of need for the expansion; or
conduct for an evidentiary hearing after conducting limited discovery; and

subparagraph.text: issue a staff report publishing the findings with respect to each factor which includes the data and analyses relied upon in reaching those findings.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall conduct a cumulative review of major energy infrastructure projects planned throughout the region of the expansion, their purported purpose and need, and their prospective impacts on State and regional energy goals, which shall be updated regularly, but no less than every five years, and that considers—

subparagraph.text: the existence of underutilized or inefficient use of existing pipeline capacity;
the effect of approval on existing customers of other pipelines;
an analysis of demonstrated regional needs for the additional natural gas, including consideration of the existence of precedent contracts;
compatibility with the State’s clean power plan, renewable energy goals, and renewable portfolio standard;

the region’s ability to meet any deficiency in energy needs through energy efficiency, dual fuel sources, LNG storage, or other economically viable and less environmentally disruptive measures than additional pipeline infrastructure;
the need for the proposed project in relation to this regional analysis.

paragraph.text: In the case of an interstate natural gas pipeline project, for purposes of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.), the Commission shall consider, in addition to current requirements for environmental impact statements or environmental assessments, the cumulative impacts of other interstate natural gas pipeline projects located within the same State or States, as well as projects within 100 miles of the project, that are approved, filed with the Commission or, in the pre-filing process—

subparagraph.text: for a 1-year period prior to the filing of the project application with the Commission;
before the issuance of the draft environmental impact statement or environmental assessment; and

paragraph.text: The Commission shall require all approved and constructed natural gas pipeline projects to undertake a five-year monitoring program to confirm that the environmental impacts identified in any environmental impact statement or analysis conducted with respect to the project have been mitigated.
